newsitem.title: GERMANY: Air India could miss cargo boom from import duty cut.
newsitem.headline: Air India could miss cargo boom from import duty cut.

text.p: Air India said it could run short of cargo capacity from Germany to India in April due to the suspension of regular flights.
The airline will suspend three of its five weekly India-Germany flights from March 8 until the end of April in order to fly Moslem pilgrims to Saudi Arabia.
Air India cargo sales manager Germany, Ruediger Brasche, told Reuters the suspension would coincide with a possible upturn in German exports to India through planned cuts in import duties.
Analysts in New Delhi said on Monday that Indian finance minister P. Chidambaram might announce cuts in import duties below 50 percent in his April 1997-March 1998 budget later this week.
Brasche said that the total Germany to India cargo market ranged up to 2,000 tonnes a month.
"But from April this could increase substantially if import conditions in India are made more flexible. Cargo could rise 50 percent from a reduction in import duties," he forecast.
But Air India could miss out on this potential surge since its weekly capacity would fall 33 percent to 10 tonnes through the suspension of the Delhi flights, Brasche warned.
"The year has begun excellently but we have still struggled with too little capacity. We could have flown much more," he added.
Air India currently had a Germany market share of 15 percent, Brasche said.
